Sector Program  The Railway Sector Investment Program which is based on the 
Description  Government’s Sector Roadmap and Investment Plan for 2007—
2013  will  improve  the  performance  of  the  railway  sector  by 
implementing (i) a reform project of sector policy, organizational, 
and capacity building reforms to make Bangladesh Railway (BR) 
more  commercially  focused,  and  improve  governance  and 
accountability; and (ii) an investment project of infrastructure and 
rolling  stock  capacity  improvement  investments  to  overcome 
capacity bottlenecks in sectors where such investments are both 
economically and financially viable, e.g., the Dhaka–Chittagong 
and the Dhaka–Darsana–Khulna corridors where it can support 
major direct investment. The reform and the investment projects 
are  integrated  as  approval  of  investment  subprojects  will  be 
dependent on the implementation of specific reform actions.  
   
Rationale  Efficient  transport  is  essential  to  achieve  higher  levels  of 
economic  growth  needed  for  sustainable  poverty  reduction  in 
Bangladesh. BR has been losing market share and consequently 
making financial losses thus relying on Government budgetary 
support. This financial support has not been enough to allow for 
additional  investment  needed  in  critical  corridors  such  as  the 
Dhaka–Chittagong  and  Dhaka–Darsana–Khulna  corridors  to 
overcome  capacity  constraints  leading  to  poor  operational 
performance of the railways. This in turn causes it to lose market 
share thus worsening its financial performance. Greater use of 
railways will ease the pressure on land since Bangladesh has a 
very high population density and land is scare. It will also ease the 
pressure on the road network, which is congested in key corridors 
and thus benefit transport as a whole. This will require capital 
investments and reforms to ensure that the investments lead to a 
sustainable  improvement  in  BR’s  operational  and  financial 
performance.

ii   
Impact and Outcome  The  Investment  Program  will  promote  sustainable  national 
economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  in  Bangladesh.  It  will 
achieve this by improving rail transport efficiency and capacity, 
thus  lowering  operating  costs  for  users  and  increasing  the 
competitiveness  of  Bangladesh  for  investment.  Foreign  direct 
investment totaling $5 billion by 2012 is currently expected. These 
investments are expected to increase Bangladesh’s GDP by 2.9% 
or $60 billion over 30 years. A prerequisite of these investments is 
that the BR is reformed and capacity constraints alleviated as 
proposed under the Investment Program.  
   
Program Investment Plan   The Government’s Railway Sector Roadmap and Investment Plan 
requires  a  total  investment  of  $924.5  million  of  which  the 
Investment Program to be implemented in five loans is estimated 
at $537.5 million, including taxes and duties of $43 million.  
   
Multitranche Financing  The Government asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
Facility  extend  financing  of  $430  million  over  5  years  through  a 
  multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF).  This  financing  represents 
46.5% of the total financing envisaged under the Government’s 
Investment Program and covers investment, reform, and capacity 
building interventions. The MFF has a maximum utilization period 
of 7 years. Individual periodic financing requests (PFR) will be 
converted into individual or separate loans. The Government has 
entered into a framework financing agreement (FFA) with ADB. 
The FFA satisfies the requirements set forth in Pilot Financing 
Instruments and Modalities. Pursuant to the FFA, the Government 
has submitted to ADB a PFR for $100 million from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources (OCR) and $30 million from Asian Development 
Fund (ADF) resources. The PFR for these two loans is presented 
to the Board, together with the FFA. Prior to acceptance of a PFR, 
ADB will ensure that the Government and BR comply in full with 
the terms and conditions of the FFA. ADB teams will conduct due 
diligence  on  these  to  ensure  that  they  are  being  satisfactorily 
adhered to. The minimum loan size will be $30 million.

iv   
   
Procurement   All  contracts  will  use  international  competitive  bidding. 
Procurement  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Procurement 
Guidelines.  
 
International and national consultants will be required to support 
the reform and investment projects of the Investment Program 
The consultants financed under the MFF loans will be engaged 
using  ADB's  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  procedures  in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The 
Government has asked ADB to select the consultants.  
   
Investment Program  Implementation of the Investment Program will improve the overall 
Benefits and  efficiency of BR and transportation in the country, contributing to 
Beneficiaries  economic growth, employment creation, and income growth. It will 
also  allow  the  release  of  Government  funds  from  budgetary 
support of the railways to other poverty reduction uses. These 
benefits  will  be  widely  disseminated  across  the  country.  The 
primary  quantifiable  economic  benefits  comprise  (i)  railway 
operating cost savings arising from faster travel times for both 
goods and passenger services; (ii) savings in operating costs for 
freight and passenger traffic arising from traffic diverted from road 
to rail made possible with the increase in rail capacity; (iii) savings 
in working capital loss for freight traffic arising from time savings, 
including elimination of waiting times to get slots on railways for 
goods being transported; (vi) time savings for passengers arising 
from faster train travel times; (vii) facilitation of investment that 
otherwise  would  not  take  place  because  an  efficient  railway 
system  is  a  prerequisite  for  such  investment;  and  (viii) 
employment opportunities to poor people during construction. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The most significant risk for the Investment Program is that the 
reform measures will not be implemented in full and therefore 
improvements in sector performance will be less than expected. 
The  assumptions  are  that  other  factors  affecting  investment, 
export growth, and economic development are in place; and the 
political and security situation remains stable so that investors are 
not deterred by political risk factors. Economic growth is assumed 
to remain strong to ensure strong demand for rail services.  
   
Technical Assistance  Advisory technical assistance of $2,000,000 will be provided for 
Institutional Support for Railway Reforms. The proposed TA will 
cover fielding of international and national consultants to provide 
(i) advisory support to BR for reform implementation, (ii) improve 
railway operation and maintenance practices; and (iii) carry out 
procurement and performance audit. The TA will be financed on a 
grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program and is attached to the 
ADF loan.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the Railway 
Sector Investment Program, and (ii) proposed technical assistance (TA) for Institutional Support 
for Railway Reforms. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Introduction 
2.  During  the  past  decade  Bangladesh  achieved  an  annual  average  gross  domestic 
product (GDP) growth rate of 5%. However, to achieve poverty reduction targets and related 
millennium development goals, a sustained annual GDP growth rate of from 7%–8% is needed.1 
As transport plays a crucial role in facilitating economic development, a safe, efficient, and 
economical  transport  system  will  support  economic  growth  and  thus  contribute  to  poverty 
reduction. Between 1971 and 2005, annual transport demand by all mechanized modes in 
Bangladesh increased by about 6% for passenger traffic and about 5% for freight. The share of 
rail transport steadily declined from 30% in 1974 to 13% in 2005 for passenger traffic and from 
28% to 7% for freight. The shift in modal split toward roads resulted from steady investments 
and improvements in road transport coupled with a decline in the quality and efficiency of rail 
services. Greater use of railways will ease pressure on land; Bangladesh’s very high population 
density means that land is scarce. It will also ease pressure on the road network, which is 
congested in key corridors, and thus benefit transport as a whole. The Government, in its 
National  Strategy  for  Accelerated Poverty  Reduction,  identifies  development  of  the  railway 
sector as important for poverty reduction because railways play a key role in accelerating 
economic growth by reducing transport costs and improving the country’s competitiveness for 
foreign and domestic direct investment.  
 
3.  Bangladesh  Railway  (BR),  a  department  under  the  Ministry  of  Communications, 
comprises  a  rail  network  of  2,855  route-kilometers  (km)  and  34,168  regular  employees. 
Supplementary Appendix A provides BR’s organization chart. The network is divided into two 
zones: east and west, separated by the Jamuna River. The rail network includes 660 km of 
broad gauge track within the West Zone, i.e., 1.676 meter width track. In addition the West Zone 
has 553 km of meter gauge i.e., 1.0 meter width track. The East Zone has 1,277 km of meter 
gauge track,, and 365 km of dual gauge track (catering for both broad and meter gauge trains). 
Jamuna Multipurpose Bridge, which has a dual gauge rail link, provides the only east–west rail 
link. Appendix 2 provides a sector analysis of the railway sector.  
 
2.  Traffic 
4.  BR operates a mix of passenger and freight services. Passenger services dominate, 
accounting for over 83% of all traffic units2 in fiscal year (FY) 2005. Passenger traffic rose 
steadily until 1983 when it reached a peak of 106 million passengers, then declined to about 40 
million  passengers  in  FY2005.  Passenger-km  traveled  also  declined,  although  to  a  lesser

FY2005, the traffic in terms of passenger-km was 4.16 billion. Passenger operations are divided 
into three types of services: intercity trains, mail/express trains, and local passenger trains. 
During FY2005, about 40% of passengers traveled on intercity trains, 37% on mail/express

services are unprofitable, with intercity trains being a notable exception. Revenue from intercity 
trains accounts for 73% of total passenger earnings. 
 
5.  The  importance  of  freight  operations  for  BR  is  highlighted  by  the  fact  that,  while 
accounting for less than 17% of total traffic units, their contribution to gross revenues in FY2005 
was nearly 34%. Freight traffic of 3.2 million tons in FY1983 decreased to 2.6 million tons in 
FY1996, but then increased during FY2005 to 3.2 million tons corresponding to 819 million ton-
km. BR’s core business in freight revolves around five commodities: food grains, containers, 
petroleum products, fertilizer, and stones; together they make up about 72% of total freight 
traffic.  Container  traffic  between  Dhaka  and  Chittagong  represents  an  important  growth 
potential. 
 
3.  Operational Performance 
 
6.  In  view  of  the  high  investment  cost  of  railway  infrastructure,  the  intensity  of  track 
utilization is an important dimension of productivity. Locomotive, coach, and wagon productivity 
are indicators of efficiency of utilization of a railway’s assets, while staff productivity measures 
the  efficiency  of  staff  utilization.  BR’s  track  utilization;  locomotive,  coach,  and  wagon 
productivity, as well as staff productivity figures are lower than that of other developing countries 
in the South and Southeast Asian regions.  
 
7.  BR’s loss of traffic partly explains the low productivity and operational performance 
statistics;  if  traffic  was  at  the  levels  of  the  1970s  and  1980s,  then  the  productivity  and 
operational performance statistics would look better. However, the statistics also reflect the 
reality that BR’s staffing was allowed to grow too large and BR has not been using its assets 
efficiently.  Labor  costs,  which  consumed  59.6%  of  operating  expenses  in  FY1992,  were 
gradually reduced to 41.5% in FY2005. This is the result of the voluntary staff separation 
program implemented with Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance.3 One of BR’s most 
serious operational problems is lack of capacity on its busiest routes, in particular the Dhaka–
Chittagong and the Dhaka–Darsana–Khulna corridors. Many sections on these corridors have 
already reached their maximum desirable line capacity. This results in low average speeds, low 
rolling stock turnaround times, and longer waiting times for cargo to find slots on wagons. 
Containers from Chittagong bound for Dhaka need to wait about 5–7 days to find a slot on 
container trains. 
 
8.  Accidents, especially derailments, are another operational problem. In FY2005, the BR 
network including main lines, branch lines, and yards, had a total of 566 derailments, i.e., an 
increase  of  3%  compared  with  FY2004.  Although  these  derailments  did  not  result  in  any 
fatalities or injuries, they did cause delays in train operations and availability, and point to the 
need for BR to improve operation and maintenance practices.

  4.  Tariffs 
 
9.  Since BR has been tasked to meet social as well as economic objectives, social and 
political factors have often outweighed commercial considerations in the process of tariff setting. 
As  a  result,  passenger  services  have  been  underpriced  and  cross-subsidized  by  freight 
services.  Compared  with  other  countries,  the  ratio  of  BR’s  average  passenger  fare  per 
passenger-km to average freight tariff per ton-km is very low. The ratio for Bangladesh is 0.26 
compared with 1.2 for the People’s Republic of China, 2.2 for Japan, and 0.7 for Thailand. 
Passenger  services  account  for  83%  of  BR’s  services,  but  contribute  only  58%  of  gross 
revenues.  
 
  5.  Outsourcing 
 
10.  Although no major privatization initiative has materialized, BR has introduced some 
private sector participation into segments of its activities with a view to augmenting its financial 
performance and ensuring some customer orientation. The private sector has been active in the 
following areas through outsourcing: 
 
(i)  commercial activities of passenger trains, 
(ii)  onboard services on intercity trains, 
(iii)  computerized ticketing and reservation systems, 
(iv)  operation of fiber optic telecommunications network, 
(v)  rehabilitation of passenger coaches, 
(vi)  cleaning of engines and passenger coaches, 
(vii)  conversion of non-air-conditioned coaches to air-conditioned, and 
(viii)  rehabilitation and maintenance of selected tracks. 
 
11.  To date, the private sector is carrying out ticketing on 76 mail/local passenger trains 
through outsourcing. This arrangement has provided BR with additional annual revenue of 
Tk132 million from these 76 trains compared with when it ran the services itself. BR also obtains 
Tk860 million a year from the leasing of its fiber optic cable network to the private sector. 
 
6.  Financial Performance 
12.  Like many other railways, BR is a loss-making entity. In FY2005, BR’s revenue was 
Tk4,456 million and operational costs Tk6,590 million, resulting in a loss of Tk2,134 million. The 
working ratio, i.e., operating expenses divided by total revenues, is 1.36; and the operating ratio, 
i.e.,  operating  expenses  divided  by  operating  revenues,  is  1.46  excluding  provision  of 
depreciation and public service obligation payments and welfare grants. Operating revenues are 
not sufficient to cover operating expenses. The financial performance steadily declined since 
FY2000 as a result of stagnant passenger tariffs and freight volume. To make up for the losses, 
the  Government  has  been  subsidizing  BR  through  deficit  financing.  The  staff  separation 
program in 1997–1998 only temporarily arrested the decline in financial performance. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
  1.  Challenges 
 
13.  BR has reached a critical juncture in its performance and is close to a cycle of decline 
experienced by many other countries’ railway services, i.e., lower revenue leading to a lack of 
maintenance  and  investments,  causing  poor  services  and  contributing  further  to  reduced

4   
revenue.  While  railways  worldwide  face  increasing  competition  from  road,  air,  and  water 
transport,  BR  faces  additional  challenges  in  overcoming  its  lack  of  commercial  focus:  low 
efficiency, poor service quality, political interference, aging fleet, and congested network on 
major corridors such as the Dhaka–Chittagong and Dhaka–Darsana–Khulna corridors. The 
weaknesses in the railway sector are manifested in declining market share, adverse operating 
indicators, and reduced revenue generation. Their underlying causes are to be found in the 
policy, institutional, and organizational arrangements for the railways, which are based on the 
idea of running railways as a social and economic arm of the Government rather than as a 
business. Supplementary Appendix B provides a cause-effect tree analysis.  
 
14.  The future performance of BR will depend on how effectively it can adapt its services to 
its changing market position. The fundamental challenges for BR are therefore to establish a 
commercial orientation with a view to (i) arresting the decline in its share of the main market 
segments; (ii) improving the profitability of its operations; and (iii) generating sufficient income to 
finance necessary investments in selective capacity expansion, asset replacement, operational 
improvements, and safety. This will require that BR (i) operate railway services using good 
business principles, (ii) concentrate on core businesses, and (iii) prioritize new investments 
based on financial and economic returns that will improve performance and capacity in major 
potential markets. These include the Dhaka–Chittagong and Dhaka–Darsana–Khulna corridors, 
which cater to Bangladesh imports and exports and can support potential major investments.  
 
2.  External Assistance 
 
15.  ADB has been the lead agency in the railway sector providing assistance to improve the 
Dhaka–Chittagong4 and  Khulna–Parbatipur  lines5 and  for  the  Jamuna  Bridge  Railway  Link 
Project.6 In addition, ADB approved a program loan for the railway sector designed to support 
the Government’s macroeconomic stabilization program (footnote 3). Other agencies previously 
active in the railway sector are the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC); and 
bilateral agencies from Canada, France, Germany, Norway, Saudi Arabia, and Spain. Appendix 
3 provides a summary of past external assistance to BR. None of the agencies mentioned 
currently has an active assistance program. However, Japan Bank for International Cooperation 
(JBIC) allowed using $25 million from its Bangladesh debt repayment forgiveness program for 
small-scale railway infrastructure improvements. The World Bank and JBIC are considering 
providing assistance to the railway sector.  
 
  3.  Lessons Learned 
 
16.  The program performance audit report for the Railway Recovery Program (footnote 3)7 
found that program loan as a lending modality was inadequate to achieve and sustain the 
program’s objective of BR breaking even against working expenses. BR faces many inherent 
physical constraints relating to inadequate infrastructure and aging rolling stock that cannot be 
addressed purely by the policy and institutional reforms pursued. Without alleviating the physical 
constraints,the  program’s  objectives  could  not  be  sustained  even  if  they  were  temporarily 
achieved and all the reforms were to be implemented. The audit report recommends that a 
sector development program8 rather than a program loan would be more effective in providing

Project. This holistic approach will enable the proposed intervention to achieve both policy 
reforms  and  infrastructure  improvements  needed  for  sustainable  improvement  of  BR’s 
operational and financial performance.  
 
17.  The program performance audit report pointed out that the 1994 program demonstrates, 
in  an  adverse  fashion,  that  policy-based  lending  cannot  be  successful  without  sustained 
commitment to reforms by the Government and concerned institutions. The report found that 
although  commitment  was  present  at  the  beginning,  it  wavered  or  was  not  passed  on  to 
successive governments or BR management teams. The same lack of commitment was seen in 
the 1997 Jamuna Bridge Railway Link Project. Although the infrastructure works in this project 
were implemented satisfactorily, the key reform covenants, e.g., becoming more commercially 
oriented and corporatizing BR were not implemented. The current Investment Program design 
therefore links investment loan approvals to implementation reform milestones to create the 
proper incentives to for the Government and BR to sustain commitment to implement reform. 
The reform itself has been carefully designed on a sequential building block basis so that 
implementation of the reform is more manageable to increase its chances of success, while at 
the  same  time  creating  an  irreversible  reform  process.  A  detailed  analysis  of  the  lessons 
learned and how the design for the current Investment Program incorporates these lessons 
learned is shown in Supplementary Appendix C.  
 
   4.  Opportunities 
 
18.  On the Dhaka–Chittagong corridor, demand for rail container and petroleum transport 
services is significant. Containers make up the most profitable freight segment, accounting for 
22% of BR’s freight revenue. The service is convenient, cheaper than by road, and popular. 
Chittagong Port receives about 600,000 TEU (twenty-foot equivalent unit) containers annually 
and the volume growth is about 15% per annum. About 75% of these are for the Dhaka area, 
i.e., about 450,000 TEU. BR is currently able to capture only a fraction of this traffic (about 
43,100 TEU or about 10%). The balance is taken to Dhaka by road, although laden containers 
cannot be taken by road between the two cities; containers are first unloaded at Chittagong 
Port. This is not only wasteful in terms of resources as each container is loaded onto 3–4 lorries, 
but  also  defeats  the  economic  benefits  of  containerization.  BR’s  low  market  share  of  this 
profitable market segment mainly results from it not being able to offer more container trains 
due to infrastructure, rolling stock capacity, and management constraints. Currently containers 
have to wait 5–7 days to secure a place on BR trains. Opportunities for rail freight traffic in the 
Dhaka–Darsana–Khulna corridor could materialize if planned foreign private sector investment 
totaling $5 billion for a steel mill at Ishurdi and a coal mine at Pulbari is implemented.9 If these 
proposals materialize, rail freight traffic is projected to increase by 10 million tons by 2010 and 
15 million tons by 2015. It will also enhance regional cooperation and increase trade between 
Bangladesh and India. Private sector parties involved in these proposals have informed the 
Government  that  reform  of  rail  organization  as  well  as  infrastructure  improvements  are 
prerequisites for the proposed projects to be implemented.

19.  Intercity trains have emerged as the most popular and only profitable component of BR 
passenger services; they carry about 40% of passengers while contributing about 73% of 
passenger revenue. Nonrevenue (ticketless) travel is not possible on intercity trains, which only 
have  reserved  seat  accommodation.  BR  runs  four  intercity  trains  between  Dhaka  and 
Chittagong daily. They run full and demand growth is pronounced. Their speeds, journey time, 
and fares are competitive with road service. The trains complete the 321 km journey in 6–7 
hours at a cost of Tk130, compared with 5 hours by road (the road distance is shorter—270 km) 
at Tk150 per passenger. However, due to lack of line capacity and low throughput on the 
corridor, more intercity trains cannot be introduced to satisfy the latent demand. Increased 
railway modal share for freight and passengers in the Dhaka–Chittagong corridor will also 
benefit the corridor transport network by relieving congestion in the road network. Thus road 
users will also benefit from faster travel times, lower operating costs, and reduced negative 
externalities such as incremental pollution from traveling in congested traffic.  
 
  5.  ADB Strategy 
 
20.  Improving the efficiency of the railway sector to address transport bottlenecks is one of 
the main elements of ADB’s country strategy and program for Bangladesh for 2006–2010 
(footnote 1). Improved transport infrastructure and services are essential to improve the overall 
investment  climate,  and  thus,  achieve  the  higher  levels  of  economic  growth  needed  for 
sustainable development and poverty reduction. More efficient railway services will facilitate 
economic growth. This will raise incomes and create employment, thereby helping to reduce 
poverty.  Improved  financial  performance  by  BR  will  reduce  the  need  to  finance  railway 
investments and operating expenditure from budgetary sources, thereby, freeing up resources 
to be used for other priority sectors. The country strategy and program also points out that 
because Bangladesh has a very high population density and tremendous land scarcity, the 
railway system needs to play a much more prominent role in the transport system. This is 
especially true in areas where rail can operate at lower costs and with less environmental 
damage. ADB’s sector strategy aims to bring about overall improvements in the railway sector 
by (i) supporting policy, organizational, and legal reforms to restructure BR to a market-oriented 
business organization with improved financial governance, human resource, and operational 
systems; and eventually to be transformed into a new government-owned corporate entity; and 
(ii) financing economically and financially viable investments in strategic rail corridors of the 
country.  
 
6.  Sector Road Map 
 
21.  ADB has engaged in intensive policy dialogue with the Government to improve railway 
sector performance. As a result of this policy dialogue the Government has agreed with ADB on 
a sector road map. The road map outlines sector (i) objectives, (ii) policies, (iii) reforms, and (iv) 
investments. The objective is to increase the freight carried by rail along the Dhaka–Chittagong 
and Dhaka–Darsana–Khulna corridors by 115% each,, as well as increase the modal share of 
rail containers from 12% to 26%. The policies outlined in the road map are to (i) improve the 
institutional capability of BR, (ii) enhance the operational capacity of BR, (iii) obtain a greater 
share of the freight market, (iv) improve financial efficiency, (vi) ensure efficient provision and 
management of railway infrastructure, (vii) reduce involvement in nonrail activities, (vii) improve 
railway safety, and (viii) encourage greater private sector participation in railways. The railway 
reform and institutional strengthening program formulated in the sector road map in line with the 
policies are to (i) restructure BR by line of business (LOB), (ii) improve financial governance, (iii) 
improve human resource governance, (iv) transform BR into a government-owned corporate 
entity,  and  (v)  improve  BR  operation  and  maintenance.  The  reform  and  institutional

7
strengthening actions will be complemented by the investment program outlined in the sector 
road map. These include (i) double-tracking in the Dhaka–Chittagong corridor, (ii) improving 
signaling along the Dhaka–Chittagong and Dhaka–Darsana–Khulna corridors, (iii) rehabilitating 
yards and extending loop lines, and (iv) procuring rolling stock. Improving the operational and 
financial efficiency of BR will enable a reduction in budget support to BR. The details of the 
sector road map are given in Appendix 4.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
22.  The  Railway  Sector  Investment  Program  is  based  on  the  Government’s  Sector 
Roadmap and Investment Plan for 2007-2013 The Investment Program will promote sustainable 
national economic growth and poverty reduction in Bangladesh. It will achieve this by improving 
rail transport efficiency and capacity, thus lowering operating costs for users and increasing the 
competitiveness of Bangladesh for investment. Foreign direct investment totaling $5 billion by 
2012 is currently expected. These investments are expected to increase Bangladesh’s GDP by 
2.9% or $60 billion over 30 years. A prerequisite of these investments is that BR is reformed 
and capacity constraints alleviated as proposed under this Investment Program.  
 
B.  Outputs 
23.  The  Investment  Program  will  ensure  that  BR  becomes  a  commercially  focused  rail 
service provider, and that rail infrastructure and rolling stock constraints are alleviated. It will 
have two mutually reinforcing components, i.e., the Reform Project and the Investment Project. 
The proposed reforms will help ensure that the proposed investment to increase capacity will 
lead to a sustainable improvement in BR’s operational and financial performance. 
 
24.  Investment Project. This will finance priority investments, i.e., those that strengthen 
BR’s  core  business  activities  and  that  form  part  of  BR’s  main  route  network.  Investment 
subprojects will concentrate on enhancing capacity to overcome constraints to increasing rail 
services in the Dhaka–Chittagong and Dhaka–Darsana–Khulna corridors where demand for 
intercity train passenger and freight (principally transportation of containers, iron and steel, coal, 
and petroleum products) services is high. The investments will be part of the Government’s 
railway sector Investment Plan to be implemented over 7 years ending in FY2013. The total 
estimated cost of the Investment Plan is $887 million, of which $500 million will be financed by 
the Investment Project. The Investment Project will finance improvement of signal systems and 
loop lines, rehabilitation of bridges, and procurement of rolling stock. This will be carried out 
using four loans. Details of the Government’s investment plan are in Supplementary Appendix 
D. 
 
25.  Reform Project. The Reform Project covers 2007–2010 and is part of the Government’s 
Sector  Roadmap.  The  reforms  and  actions  will  make  BR  more  market-oriented  through 
reorganization  by  LOB,  with  better  financial  governance  and  human  resource  governance 
systems; transform it into a government-owned corporate entity; and improve rail safety. The 
total estimated cost for the Reform Project implementation is $37.5 million.

  1.  Linkage of Loan Approvals to Reform Achievement 
 
31.  The Investment Program is designed as a strategic integration of sector policy reforms, 
institutional development,  and  investment.  Investment  Program  loan  approvals  for  capacity 
improvement  will  be  directly  linked  to  the  achievement  of  specific  reform  actions.  The 
Government has already undertaken the preparatory actions agreed with ADB as being needed 
to ensure that reform and investment implementation can start as soon as possible using the 
ADF loan for $30 million and the first ordinary capital resources (OCR) loan for $100 million. 
Approval  of  the  second  OCR  loan  for  $150  million  will  be  dependent  on  the  successful

corporate entity and establishing a rail safety regulatory body. A project agreement with the 
government-owned BR corporate entity will be needed at that time.  
 
  2.  Improving Sector and Corporate Governance 
 
32.  The design of the Reform Project incorporates measures to improve governance at three 
levels, i.e., sector, corporate, and project. The reform elements are specifically designed to 
improve sector and corporate governance of the railway sector. The introduction of modern 
financial management and accounting systems is to ensure that financial governance within BR 
is improved. The new system, which will be computer-based, will incorporate computerized 
audit trails to ensure that internal and external auditing and tracking will be up to internationally 
accepted standards. Audit trails will also improve transparency in tracking cash and financial 
approvals and decision-making from the station up to the corporate headquarters. The financial 
statements produced using the new system will be based on internationally accepted practices 
for the railway sector, and provide transparency and rationality to sector decision-making on 
financial issues such as tariff-setting and calculation of public service obligation payments. 
Corporate  governance  will  also  be  improved  with  the  introduction  of  human  resource 
management  systems  under  the  reform  program.  Key  performance  indicators  will  be 
established for top management who will be held accountable for achieving the planned results. 
A more detailed analysis of how the Reform Project is designed to improve governance and its 
relationship to other ADB initiatives being implemented to improve national governance as well 
as anticorruption measures at the project level is shown in Supplementary Appendix F.

V.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
47.  The Reform Project will enable BR to restructure itself into an LOB organizational structure 
with distinct cost and profit centers, and improved financial governance and human resource 
governance. It will enable BR to have accurate asset registers, and modern financial accounting 
and management systems. This will enable BR to have greater commercial focus concentrating 
on distinct markets as opposed to the current government departmental focus prevalent in BR. 
Transparency  and accurate information  will be provided for policy  and operational decision-
making and service planning. Breaking away from a bureaucratic structure into a corporate 
structure will introduce greater accountability to BR managers. With a greater commercial focus, 
BR losses could be reduced if not reversed and thus the burden on the Government to finance 
these losses lessened. Improving BR’s efficiency will also help to attract greater foreign direct 
investment into the country as an efficient transportation system is one of the factors that investors 
consider. Rail reform is a prerequisite of potential investors in coal and steel projects (para. 20). 
Hence the Reform Project will directly help Bangladesh to secure these two mega investment 
projects. Furthermore as the ADB Private Sector Operations Department is considering being an 
investor in the steel project, restructuring BR by LOB is also directly creating business synergies 
and opportunities between ADB’s public sector and its private sector operations. The Investment 
Project will finance infrastructure and rolling stock to alleviate capacity constraints. This will enable 
BR to carry more freight and passenger traffic while reducing the costs of transport for users, thus 
contributing to economic growth and additional earnings for BR. This will in turn reduce the 
Government’s subsidies provided to BR thus enabling the Government to devote more resources 
to other priority sectors. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Analyses 
1.  Economic Internal Rate of Return 
 
48.  The economic internal rate of return was calculated by comparing the with- and without-
subproject scenarios in the Dhaka–Chittagong rail corridor. The existing available rail corridor 
has reached capacity and will be unable to carry additional goods and passenger traffic without 
the subproject. With the subproject, the capacity of the rail corridor will be increased to be able 
to carry more goods and passenger traffic. 
 
49.  The subproject’s economic costs include the resource costs for construction, rolling 
stock acquisition costs, operation and maintenance costs, and social costs arising from land 
acquisition and  resettlement  compensation.  The  main  economic  benefits  generated  by  the 
subproject were quantified in terms of (i) railway operating cost savings arising from faster travel 
times for both goods and passenger services; (ii) savings in operating costs for both freight and 
passenger traffic arising from traffic diverted from road to rail made possible with the increase in 
rail capacity; (iii) savings in working capital loss for freight traffic arising from time savings, 
including elimination of waiting times to get slots on railways for the goods being transported; 
and (vi) time savings for passengers arising from faster train travel times. Other benefits such as 
savings in avoided road maintenance costs arising from the reduction in laden trucks using the 
road because the goods are being transported by railways; have not been considered in the 
economic evaluation, thus making this analysis conservative. The economic internal rate of 
return is estimated to be 16%, indicating that the subproject is economically viable. Sensitivity 
and  risk  analysis  indicates  that  the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  is  robust  under  most

16  
conditions. The summary of the economic and financial analysis is given in Appendix 12 and the 
full details in Supplementary Appendix L.  
 
2.  Financial Internal Rate of Return  
 
50.  The financial evaluation was completed for the subprojects required to complete double-
tracking of the Dhaka–Chittagong rail corridor. The financial evaluation was undertaken in real 
terms using constant 2005 prices. The subproject cost estimates and financial projections in 
nominal terms were converted to real terms by adjusting for the projected effects of foreign and 
domestic inflation and currency fluctuation. Incremental benefits and costs were derived by 
evaluating  the  financial  position  of  BR  under  with-  and  without-subproject  scenarios.  The 
financial internal rate of return, computed on an after-tax basis, is 14%. This compares favorably 
with the average weighted average cost of capital of 5%, also computed on an after-tax basis. 
The  subprojects  are  considered  both  financial  viable  and  sustainable.  Sensitivity  and  risk 
analyses indicate that the financial internal rate of return is robust under most conditions. The 
detailed financial evaluation is provided in Appendix 12, with further information provided in 
Supplementary Appendix L. The financial projections for BR are in Supplementary Appendix M. 
 
C.  Social Impact 
  1.  Poverty and Social Dimensions 
 
51.  The Dhaka–Chittagong corridor connects the two largest cities in Bangladesh: Dhaka, 
the  capital  (district  population  8.6  million);  Chittagong,  Bangladesh’s  main  port  (district 
population 6.6 million); and the other areas in between. Comilla (district population 5.0 million) is 
the largest of the cities within the corridor. The total population in the corridor (broadly defined) 
is 38 million. The corridor has a land area that comprises only 16% of the area of Bangladesh, 
but contains 30% of the population and accounts for 40% of the country’s GDP. Expansion of 
rail capacity in the corridor would lead to increased freight and passenger services both for 
people in this region as well as to other regions of the country thereby creating opportunities for 
economic and social development that would lead to poverty reduction. As this subproject will 
provide an efficient transport linkage from the port of Chittagong not only to Dhaka but also to 
the rest of the rail network, the Project will facilitate growth of local markets and industries 
thereby creating more employment opportunities, with substantial opportunities being passed on 
to unskilled workers of the area.  
52.  The  benefit  of  the  improved  rail  transportation  facilities  will  be  enjoyed  by 
consigners/consignees  since  rail  freight  tariffs  are  lower  than  truck  charges  thereby  also 
reducing the cost of goods. With faster and more reliable services of passenger and intercity 
trains, travelers will increase trip frequency for both business and other purposes, and this will 
increase  labor  mobility.  The  subproject  will  also  reduce  poverty  by  providing  employment 
opportunities for local residents, especially the poor, during construction and operation. It will 
provide increased business opportunities to the suppliers of goods and services to the railways 
and thus generate more employment opportunities. The improvement of the rail network will 
enable  the  people,  especially  the  poor  in  the  Dhaka–Chittagong  corridor  to  have  greater 
accessibility to other infrastructure services, for example schools, universities, and hospitals, as 
the travel time will be decreased enabling them to reach such facilities more efficiently and on 
time. A summary poverty reduction and social strategy is presented in Appendix 13.

D.  Environmental Impact 
54.  Transport, especially vehicle emission, is the highest contributor to Bangladesh’s air 
pollution problems. Improving the railway network will contribute significantly to reducing air 
pollution associated with vehicle emission especially in Chittagong, Dhaka and Khulna. The

to increasing uncontrolled exploitation of natural resources. However, the gradual improvement 
in enforcing the Environmental Conservation Act, 1995 is expected to minimize the potential 
uncontrolled  exploitation  of  natural  resources  and  the  environment.  Nonetheless,

E.  Risks 
56.  The  most  significant  risk  for  the  Program  is  that  the  reform  measures  will  not  be 
implemented in full and therefore that improvements in sector performance will be less than 
expected. This risk has been mitigated by linking reform and investment, whereby the key steps 
in the reform process are conditions for approvals of subsequent batches of subprojects, thus 
giving an incentive to BR to implement the reforms. The sequencing of the reforms has been 
carefully designed so that they are implemented in incremental irreversible steps to discourage 
any backsliding. Instead of transforming BR into a government-owned corporate entity in one 
single step, the internal reorganization is implemented first, together with putting into place the 
appropriate financial and human resource governance systems. Once visible success in the 
form of greater financial and operational performance is achieved in these initial steps, the 
reform  process  will  gain  added  credibility,  which  will  discourage  backsliding,  and  thus  the 
transformation of BR into a government-owned corporate entity can be achieved more easily.  
 
57.  Linking investment subproject approvals to achievement of reform actions carries the 
risk  that  investment  subprojects  will  be  delayed  because  the  relevant  reform  actions  are 
implemented late. This risk has been mitigated by preparing a realistic reform road map that 
gives a buffer period between when a particular reform action will be fully implemented and a 
deadline when that reform action is due to enable submission of a PFR for an investment 
component loan.  
 
58.  On the investment side, the main risk for the Program is that implementation will be 
delayed, especially initially as the PIU gets accustomed to its working arrangements. This risk is 
considered slight as the project completion report for the Jamuna Bridge Railway Link Project 
showed that BR has good project management and implementation capacity. This risk has been 
further  mitigated  with  the  Government  asking  ADB  to  carry  out  the  selection  for  both  the 
consulting contracts to prepare the civil works contracts and the reform implementation to be 
financed under the Program so that no bureaucratic delays occur in this initial period before the 
PIU is functioning at optimum efficiency. The Government has also agreed that FIDIC conditions 
will be used so that the construction supervision consultant as “Engineer” in the contract will 
have sufficient authority to direct the contractors. On the whole, the integrated benefits and 
impacts are expected to outweigh the costs, given the likelihood of risks occurring.

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  Privately owned regional railways were built in what is now Bangladesh during colonial 
times to support commerce and passenger movements.1 These were gradually taken over by 
the Government, with the nationalization process being completed by 1942. After independence 
in 1947, control of railways falling within the boundaries of what is now Bangladesh was with the 
central government of Pakistan. A Railway Board was formed in 1962 and management of the 
railways  was  placed  under  the  then  East  Pakistan  provincial  government.  With  the 
independence of Bangladesh, the railways were renamed Bangladesh Railway (BR).  
 
2.  BR, a department under the Ministry of Communications, has a network of 2,855 route-
kilometers (km) and 34,168 regular employees. It is headed by a Director General who is 
assisted by five Additional Director Generals, one Rector of the Training Academy, one Chief 
Planning Officer, and seven Joint Director Generals. The network is divided into two zones: the 
east and west, separated by the Jamuna River. Each zone is headed by a General Manager 
who is responsible to the director general. Each zone is in turn divided into two geographic 
divisions,  which  form  the  basic  unit  of  operation.  The  BR  Director  General  reports  to  the 
Secretary of the Ministry of Communications and thereafter to the Minister of Communications. 
The nine-member Bangladesh Railway Authority headed by the Minister of Communications 
provides policy guidance. Supplementary Appendix A provides BR’s organization chart. 
 
3.  The rail network comprises two gauges, including 660 km of broad gauge, i.e., 1.676 
meter width track, in the West Zone. In addition, the West Zone has 553 km of meter gauge, 
i.e., 1.0 meter width track, and the East Zone has 1,277 km of meter gauge track. At present, 
the meter gauge networks of the two zones are linked by railway ferry crossing over the Jamuna 
River between Bhahadurabad and Fulchari (Balashi) Ghat at the upper section. In addition the 
network has 365 km of dual gauge track (catering for both broad and meter gauge trains). The 
Jamuna Multipurpose Bridge, which has a dual gauge railway link, provides the only east–west 
rail link. However, its utility to BR is limited by the significant load restrictions placed on broad 
gauge trains crossing the bridge. BR has a total of 454 stations, 243 in the east and 211 in west 
zones. It has 277 locomotives, 1,407 passenger and other coaches, and 10,631 wagons.

  3.  Tariffs 
 
11.  Since BR has been tasked to meet social as well as economic objectives, social and 
political factors have often outweighed commercial considerations in the process of tariff setting. 
As  a  result,  passenger  services  have  been  underpriced  and  cross-subsidized  by  freight 
services. As the national carrier, BR has the obligation to carry essential commodities like food 
grains, fertilizer, jute, cement, coal, iron and steel, stone and boulders, petroleum products, salt, 
and sugar to remote areas at a cheaper rate. Compared with other countries, the ratio of BR’s 
average passenger fare per passenger-km to average freight tariff per ton-km is very low. The 
ratio for Bangladesh is 0.5 compared with 1.2 for the People’s Republic of China, 22.0 for 
Japan,  and  0.7  for  Thailand.  Passenger  services  account  for  83%  of  BR’s  services  but 
contribute only 58% of gross revenues.  
 
C.  Challenges 
 
12.  Institutionally, BR’s main problem is linked to its civil service department status, which 
has limited its managerial and operational autonomy considerably while exacerbating its lack of 
commercial and marketing orientation. It is therefore not in a position to take rapid business 
decisions to focus on market segments where rail has a comparative advantage over other 
modes. Decisions such as tariffs to be charged, staff deployment, abandonment of unprofitable 
passenger lines, and all major investment decisions have to be referred to the Government 
under normal service rules and practices. The delays inherent in such a process have often 
meant loss of business opportunities. 
 
13.  BR has reached a critical juncture in its performance and is close to a cycle of decline 
experienced by many other countries’ railway services, i.e., lower revenue leading to a lack of 
maintenance and investment, resulting in poor services and contributing to reduced revenue. 
While railways worldwide face increasing competition from road, air, and water transport, BR 
faces additional challenges in overcoming its lack of commercial focus, low efficiency, poor 
service quality, political interference, aging fleet, and congested network on major corridors 
such as Dhaka–Chittagong. The weaknesses in the railway sector are manifested in declining 
market share, adverse operating indicators, and reduced revenue generation. Their underlying 
causes are to be found in the policy, institutional, and organizational arrangements for the 
railways, which are based on the idea of running railways as a social and economic arm of the 
Government rather than as a business. A cause-effect tree analysis is shown in Supplementary 
Appendix B. However railways have the potential to be an efficient form of transport for certain 
critical market segments. A balanced transport system whereby railways can achieve their 
potential in market segments where they are economically and financially competitive will help 
in the economic growth of the country and ensure that the investment already made in the 
system can be utilized efficiently.  
 
14.  The future performance of BR will depend on how effectively it can adapt its services to 
its changing market position. The fundamental challenges for BR are therefore to establish a 
commercial orientation with a view to (i) arresting the decline in its share of the main market 
segments; (ii) improving the profitability of its operations; and (iii) generating sufficient income to 
finance necessary investments in selective capacity expansion, asset replacement, operational 
improvements, and safety. This will involve BR (i) operating railway services along business 
lines; (ii) concentrating on core businesses; and (iii) prioritizing investments based on financial 
and economic returns with a view to improving operational performance and capacity in major 
potential markets, e.g., Dhaka–Chittagong. Another potentially profitable route for BR is the

ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSES 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Dhaka–Chittagong rail corridor has a total length of 321 kilometers (km), with 121 
km doubled-tracked. Double tracking the Tongi–Bhairab Bazar section is the sample subproject 
of the Investment Project of the Railway Sector Investment Program. Double tracking the other 
sections will be financed by other sources or as another subproject. Hence, all single-track 
sections will be double-tracked within the Project’s time frame. Because of the impact of the 
corridor network, economic and financial analyses must be carried out for double-tracking all of 
the 200 km of single-tracked sections.  
 
B.  Traffic Forecasts 
 
2.  Bangladesh Railway (BR) data shows that for fiscal year (FY) 2005, the passenger 
volume in the Dhaka–Chittagong corridor was 1,422 million passenger-km for intercity services; 
this is growing at 6.1% per annum. For FY2005, the freight volume in the Dhaka–Chittagong 
corridor was 144 million ton-km for container services and 108 million ton-km for other cargo. 
BR statistics show that container volume grew at 8% per annum and other cargo by 5%. All the 
existing lines in the subproject corridors have already reached their capacity; after 2008, no 
additional freight traffic growth is expected to be possible. When the subproject is open for 
service in 2009, rail capacity will double, and boost the annual growth rate substantially, i.e., 
25% for containers, 17% for other freight, and 10% for intercity train passengers before the

C.  Costs

diverted from road to rail made possible with the increase in rail capacity, (iii) savings in working 
capital loss for freight traffic arising from time savings including elimination of waiting times to 
get slots on railways for the goods being transported, and (iv) time savings for passengers 
arising  from  faster  train  travel  times.  Other  benefits,  such  as  savings  in  avoided  road 
maintenance costs arising from the reduction in laden trucks using the road because the goods

and  regain  their  businesses.  All  CBEs,  irrespective  of  titled/nontitled  owners  of  business 
premises, will receive a cash grant for loss of access to business premise, plus shifting or 
moving allowance, and one-time cash grant for loss of income. This assistance is intended to 
supplement CBEs duration transitional period to reestablish businesses in new locations. 
12.   Institutional Framework. BR will implement the RP by setting up a resettlement unit 
within the project implementation unit, which will be established for the Investment Project. The 
resettlement unit, under the overall responsibility of the project director, will implement the RP. 
The resettlement unit will have one deputy director at headquarters and one deputy director in 
the field who will implement the plan. The resettlement unit staff will be trained after deployment. 
The project director will confirm the land acquisition with assistance of district administrations 
and deputy directors (Resettlement). Upon clearance of the land acquisition proposal by the 
deputy commissioner or Ministry of Land, a PVAT will be formed through Government gazette to 
recommend  replacement  market  price  of  land  and  other  properties.  PVAT  will  have 
representatives from BR in the chair, representative from the implementing NGO as the member 
secretary, and representative from the deputy commissioners. An implementing NGO will be 
contracted to assist the resettlement unit in implementing the resettlement tasks. The NGO will 
collect,  collate,  computerize,  and  process  data  for  identification  of  eligible  people  for 
resettlement benefits and assess their entitlements as per RP policy. The resettlement unit will 
effect the payments after necessary scrutiny.  
 
13.  GRCs  will  be  established  with  representation  from  BR,  those  affected, 
women/vulnerable groups, local government, and NGOs. Those affected can call upon the 
support of NGOs to assist them in presenting their grievances or queries to the GRC. The 
deputy director, resettlement, field, will chair the GRC. Other than disputes relating to ownership 
right under the court of law, the GRC will review grievances involving all resettlement benefits, 
relocation, and other assistance. Grievances will be redressed within a month from the date of

64  Appendix 14 
lodging the complaints. To ensure people’s participation, the NGO will form a resettlement 
advisory  committee  comprising  local  leaders,  both  men  and  women,  such  as  people's 
representatives, teachers, imams, knowledgeable persons, headmen, etc. The committee will 
advise on the best ways to implement the RP smoothly and efficiently. The GRCs, resettlement 
advisory committees, as well as the JVT and PVAT formed and activated during the land 
acquisition process will allow those affected sufficient time to lodge complaints and safeguard 
their recognized interests.  
14.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement Budget and Financing. The land acquisition and 
resettlement  budget  includes  all  costs  for  acquisition  of  assets  and  costs  associated  with 
involuntary  resettlement.  The  management  and  implementation  of  RP  activities  include 
additional studies for needs assessment, capacity building, hiring NGO for implementation, 
transport, monitoring and evaluation, etc. The total estimated cost is Tk216.09 million ($3.712 
million) and will be financed by the Government. At this stage, the costs can be considered as 
estimates and will be revised after updating the RP database during implementation.

15.  RP Implementation Schedule. The RP will be implemented from April 2007 over 3 
years. BR will initiate some advance actions such as the establishment of the resettlement unit; 
identification of resettlement staff in the field offices; formation of PVAT and GRCs; and hiring of 
an NGO for resettlement implementation following loan negotiations. The overall schedule of RP 
implementation is based on the principle that people affected by land acquisition are paid their 
legal compensation and due resettlement benefits prior to relocation. House transfer will be 
assisted  prior  to  or  during  relocation  of  the  households  from  the  right-of-way.  The  RP 
implementation schedule may be revised as per field situation in consultation with BR and 
concurrence from ADB.  
16.  Monitoring and Evaluation. Land acquisition and resettlement implementation will be 
supervised  and  monitored  by  the  project  director  in  coordination  with  the  deputy  director-
resettlement,  BR  field  staff,  construction  supervision  consultant,  and  the  resettlement-
implementing  NGO.  The  monitoring  will  be  done  both  internally  and  externally  to  provide 
feedback  to  BR  and  to  assess  the  effectiveness  of  the  RP  implementation  process.  A 
computerized  management  information  system  will  be  in  operation  for  monitoring  RP 
implementation.  The  internal  monitoring  by  BR  will  deal  with  all  aspects  of  relocation, 
resettlement,  and  rehabilitation  of  the  households.  The  field  deputy  director-resettlement, 
assisted  by  the  RP  implementing  NGO  will  conduct  field  monitoring  and  assess  the  daily 
operation of resettlement activities.  
 
17.  The resettlement specialist of the construction supervision consultant will supervise, 
monitor, and assist RP implementation. The supervision and monitoring work will involve review 
of resettlement implementation, verification of the results of internal monitoring in the field, and 
consultation with those affected, officials, and community leaders for preparing review reports.

Monthly progress reports will be prepared and submitted to the project director by the NGO. 
During the implementation, the project director will periodically send status reports to ADB on 
RP  implementation  and  a  final  report  once  the  resettlement  is  completed.  An  external 
monitoring and evaluation agency with sufficient skills and capacity in monitoring resettlement 
implementation will be assigned within 3 months of loan approval. The agency will provide a 
biannual review and report both to ADB and BR. BR will report to ADB on land acquisition, 
resettlement, and income generation program in the quarterly reports, including identification of 
signification issues.
